He and his wife will grow potatoes and harvest them in autumn. They will use some for themselves and sell the surplus to local people who are in need of quality potatoes.

loans.use: to buy potato seeds

loans.name: Baasanjargal

texts.en: Mrs. Baasanjargal, 31 years old, lives with her husband and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. She has been selling clothes to local people since 2008. During her study in Germany, she was fascinated with the quality of German clothes and after coming back to Mongolia, she began to sell German clothes for a living. Her husband is currently unemployed due to a sudden lay off from the mining company. Their daughter is five years old and goes to kindergarten. She is requesting a loan of 4000000 MNT to buy furniture such as drawers, closet and sofa for her new home. This will make her home more comfortable and give her increased enthusiasm for her work.

loans.use: to buy furniture

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 33 years old and lives in the town of Wakiso in the Kampala East region of Uganda. He is married and has 3 children, with 1 of them currently in school. For the past 6 years, Charles has been working hard to manage his small photography business. 

To help expand his business, Charles has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more cameras and other items for the business, and will help Charles to generate greater profits. This will enable him to take care of his family and pay medical bills. Charles hopes that in the future he will be able to increase his capital stock. 

Charles is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Charles who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more cameras and other items for his business

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 33 years old and lives in the town of Nansana, in the Kampala east region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past five years, Grace has been working hard to manage her tailoring business, in which she does sew clothes and a tailoring school. 

To help expand her business, Grace has requested a loan of UGX 2,500,000 (Ugandan shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more materials that will be used in her tailoring business and will help Grace to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Grace hopes that, in the future, she will be able to own a larger tailoring school,just as you can see in the photo the lady in there is being trained in tailoring. 

Grace is a member of BRAC Uganda's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs, like Grace, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more materials that will be used in her tailoring business.

loans.name: Dirisa

texts.en:
Dirisa is 30 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala East region of Uganda. He has one child who is currently in school. For the past 4 years, Dirisa has been working hard to manage his poultry farm, which sells chicken. 

To help expand his business, Dirisa has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more chicks and feeds for the farm, and will help him to generate greater profits and improve his family's standard of living. He hopes that in the future he will be able to own a large poultry farm. 

Dirisa is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Dirisa who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more chicks and feeds for the farm

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en: Jenifer lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single with seven children and four go to school. She takes care of additional family members. She operates a stall selling fish at the market on retail basis. She has been in this business for the last six years. She works seven days-a-week. She gets additional income from rearing cattle. She has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from MCDT – SACCO to buy fish. Her major challenge includes seasonality and transportation. Her goal and aspiration is to expand her business to selling fruits and vegetables. She lives in a rented space and the family has access to piped water and electricity. Her major monthly expenses include school fees.

loans.use: To buy fish to sell at the market.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is a 54-year-old married woman; she has four children. She describes herself to be dedicated and optimistic. 

Rosemary operates a farming business where she raises chickens. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. She describes her biggest business challenge to be a lack of funds. 

She will use the Kes 50,000 loan to purchase additional farm inputs to improve the production processes. 

Her business goal is to be financially stable within five years.

loans.use: to purchase additional farm inputs to improve the production processes

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 60 years old, married and with three children ages between 12 to 38 years. For the last four years she has had a business in farming whereby she both grows food crops and keeps livestock, with a monthly income of KES. 20,000.                           
	
Margaret is applying for a loan of KES 21,000 from VisionFund Kenya, to buy farm inputs such as seedlings to sell. She plans to use the anticipated income to expand her business and educate her children.
	
She hopes to have a bright future and improve her farming activity,

loans.use: to buy farm inputs such as seedlings for sale

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is a married woman. She has four children. She describes herself as successful. 

She operates a farming business where she grows vegetables. She has been involved in this business for seven years. She describes her biggest business challenge as insufficient access to funds. 

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to purchase stock of farm inputs. This is her first loan with SMEP Micro finance Bank.

loans.use: to purchase stock of farm inputs

loans.name: Ronald

texts.en:
Ronald is a married man with three children. 

He owns a bar as his business in a rural area. His main clients are the are the local community. He started his business to earn a living. He has  additional income from produce. He has hopes of completing his house.

Ronald is a hardworking man who faces a challenge of competition from other people with the same businesses. He plans to buy a pool table to attract more customers at the bar.

loans.use: to buy a pool table to attract more customers at the bar.

loans.name: Jacquelinn

texts.en:
Jacquelinn is a single woman. She describes herself to be focused. She operates a retail business where she sells clothes, and she has been involved in this business for four years. She describes her biggest business challenge to be a lack of capital. 

Jacquelinn will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. She hopes that in the future, she will own a wholesale business. This is her first loan with SMEP Micro finance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes

loans.name: Tom

texts.en: Tom is a 40-year-old hardworking man with two children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He deals in selling produce, mainly cassava and maize flour. He is facing the hardships of customers who delay payment when he could use the proceeds to re-invest in the business. In spite of this, he has a vision of working hard to register more profits. Tom needs a loan to buy cassava and grind it to flour to sell.

loans.use: to buy cassava and grind it to flour to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy sugar, bread,flour, washing soap and other items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for efficient cooking energy from Liquefied Petroleum Gas

loans.name: Ignetius

texts.en: Ignetius is a Ugandan married man living in Kagadi-Uganda. He has been operating a motorcycle spare parts shop and earns from produce selling too to generate extra income. He hopes to grow his business despite delayed payments by debtors. Ignetius is requesting a loan to buy more motorcycle spare parts for selling.

loans.use: to buy more motorcycle spare parts for selling.

loans.name: Véronique

texts.fr:
Agée de 50 ans, véronique est mariée et a en charge quatre(04) enfants à Tokoin. Elle fait du commerce du charbon depuis 2012, elle s’approvisionne à Atakpamé et revend ces sacs de charbon de bois au marché de Gbossimé et à  son domicile.
Véronique sollicite un prêt pour agrandir son commerce afin de faire assez de bénéfices et aider son mari dans les dépenses du ménage.
texts.en: Véronique is 50 years old, married, and she has four (04) children under her care.  She lives in Tokoin.  She has been selling charcoal since 2012 and stocks up in Atakpamé.  She resells bags of charcoal at the Gbossimé market and from home. Véronique is taking a loan to expand her business and to make enough profits to be in a position to help her husband cover the family's expenses.

loans.use: to buy 33 bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy food supplies.

loans.name: Jesica

texts.en:
Jesica is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kaliro, in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past five years, Jesica has been working hard to manage her carpentry business in which she sells beds, chairs, tables, and stools. 

To help expand her business, Jesica has requested a loan of UGX 500,000 (Ugandan shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy timber, nails, and other materials and will help Jesica to generate greater profits and pay house rent for her parents. Jesica hopes that, in the future, she will be able to build a house for her parents. 

Jesica is a member of BRAC Uganda's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy timber, nails, and other materials.

loans.name: Magret's Group

texts.en:
Magret's group is comprised of 2 hard working women. Magret is 20 years old and lives in the town of Zirobwe in the Luwero region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Magret has been working hard to manage her farming business, which also sells food. 

To help expand her business, Magret has requested a loan of 800,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy fertilizers for the plants and more items for the retail shop, which will help Magret to generate greater profits and improve her family's standard of living. Magret hopes that in the future she will be able to take a hairdressing course. 

Magret is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for the plants and more items for the retail shop

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa is 56 years old and lives in Dicoloc, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is married with 3 adult children. 
Rosa is engaged in managing a Sari-sari store that has sold groceries and other consumable products for the last 10 years/ She earns approximately PHP4,000.00 each month doing this type of business activity. She has requested a loan to be used in purchasing additional stocks of groceries and other consumable goods for retail.
Rosa has been a member of PMPC for almost 5 years. In the future, Rosa hopes to expand her sari-sari store business.

loans.use: To be used in purchasing additional stocks of groceries and other consumable goods

loans.name: Twekambe Mixed Farmers Kayanja Group

texts.en: Faustina is a 54-year-old married Ugandan lady living in Kagadi with eight children and six attend school. She operates a bar alongside farming to earn income. She hopes to start up a retail shop, though she has inadequate capital. Faustina intends to use a loan to buy crates of beer and sodas for selling. She is a member of Twekambe Mixed Farmers Group where each member guarantees the other to get a loan since they don’t pledge securities.

loans.use: to buy crates of beer and sodas for selling.

loans.name: Naphtali

texts.en: Naphtali is a married man. He has one child. He describes himself as being honest. He operates a retail business where he sells clothes. He has been involved in this business for three years. His business is located in a competitive area and his primary customers are of all types. He describes his biggest business challenge to be a lack of capital. He will use the 40,000 KES (Kenyan Shillings) loan to buy more stocks of clothes. His business goal is to own a big supermarket within five years. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. He will use the anticipated profits to add more stocks of clothes.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of clothes.

loans.name: Vicent

texts.en: Vicent used the previous loan to buy seedlings for planting. He practices food crop farming and crops cultivated include tomatoes, Irish potatoes, maize and beans to mention but a few. He started this business so that he could be in a position to earn a living. With the loan capital, he wants to rent tomato plantations to harvest and sell. His major hope is to have personal income to support his business and expand it. Like any other farmer, he too is affected by price fluctuations that retard his business.

loans.use: To rent tomato plantations to harvest and sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to begin his cybercafé business, to purchase machinery, equipment, and furniture to outfit his room.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a computer (laptop) for herself.

loans.name: Sylivia

texts.en: Sylivia is a repeat borrower with UGAFODE. She has applied for a loan of UGX 1,600,000 to buy clothes to sell in her business. She is a hardworking lady who now typically works every day of the week. She deals in a textile business which she started in 2009 to have an income to look after her family. Her major challenge is competition, and she hopes to compete with other business people of the same category when given the loan money. She believes she can achieve her dreams if the partnership with Kiva and UGAFODE is maintained.

loans.use: To buy two bales of clothes.

loans.name: Nyakariro Central Group

texts.en:
Guddy is a member of the Nyakariro Central Group which is comprised of six members. They are taking a loan of UGX 3,100,000. She is a resident of Rukungiri, where she operates a small-sized clinic. She is a mother of three children, and she started her business after losing her job as a nurse at a school. 

To be able to cater for her children, she started her own clinic using borrowed funds from her brother. She has been using her clinic as her major source of income, but later she discovered that her business alone could not meet all her financial needs and those of her children. However, demand for medical services at the clinic has been increasing. She therefore opted to borrow funds from UGAFODE through the group. 

She is happy that her business is going to do well and she will be able to provide for her family at the same time. She is grateful to UGAFODE and Kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her medical clinic

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en:
Kenneth, 28, is honest and hardworking. He is married and has two children. He has been able to provide his family with the basic necessities of life. 

Kenneth farms and has a milling machine that he uses to earn a living in his region. He uses the machine to mill maize, millet and ground nuts. His main challenge is when his machinery breaks down, slowing his work and causing a delay in meeting his clients’ needs.

Kenneth is applying for a loan of 2,000,0000 UGX through UGAFODE to buy a plot of land so that he can expand his farm and take further advantage of his milling machine. Kenneth’s dream is to see his business grow from small-scale milling to packaging high-quality maize flour in his region.

loans.use: to buy a plot of land

loans.name: Swazi Twetungure Group

texts.en:
Alice is a 49-year-old married woman with two children. She is a proud member of the Swazi group, which has 10 members, most of whom are farmers. Only six of the members are acquiring a loan this cycle and the seventh person in the photo on the extreme left is the group secretary who was present to sign for the group as a committee member but is resting from taking a loan. He also signed the client waiver form.
 
Alice has been a tea farmer since 2001. She works seven days a week and dedicates nine hours per day to farming. Her tea farm is located in Swazi, a cell in Kyamuhunga sub county in Bushenyi District. Tea farming is the main activity in the area and she decided to concentrate on that as the main source of income at that time. In addition to tea farming, Alice started a retail shop to supplement her income so that she can easily look after her children. The shop is located in the same area and she says it has indeed boosted her income. She hopes to use the loan to buy fertilizer to improve the quality of the soil. Alice has high hopes that the next season's harvest will be better and she will earn more money. Indeed, the previous season she did great after she added fertilizers and she is looking toward to a much bigger harvest after applying more fertilizers using this loan. Despite the challenge of weather, which affects her greatly, Alice is determined to increase the size of her farm so that she realizes bigger profits. She is very hardworking and self-motivated.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey is a hardworking man, 45 years old, who operates a transport business. The business is done in Ishaka, Bushenyi district and his customers are all categories of people. He is married with four children ages 24, 22, 20 and 18 years old, all of whom attended school. He started this business to have income to look after his family and educate his children. In addition to his transport business, he also supports his wife's salon business to supplement his monthly income. Godfrey's major challenge is competition from other businesses men and poor weather, which affects the demand for his services.

Godfrey has applied for a loan of ugx.1,300,000 Ugandan shillings to top up on a piece of land that he is acquiring. Godfrey is determined to work hard and repay his loan over time.

loans.use: to buy land

loans.name: Danyaro

texts.en: Danyaro is a 40-year-old farmer from Rafin Tabo. As a Babban Gona member, Danyaro is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Danyaro can earn up to $2,000/hectare this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Danyaro is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked about his ambitions as a Babban Gona farmer, Danyaro said, “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children; Hakilu, Dahiru and Ummaru, and in five years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high quality inputs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase goods and renovate his workplace.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for efficient and clean cooking energy from liquefied petroleum gas

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.es:
Ricardo vive en anticretico con su esposa e hija menor en la ciudad de La Paz. Tiene un automovil con el cual trabaja en transporte libre todos los dias por mas de 10 hrs. diarias.

El credito que solicita es para comprar llantas para su movilidad ya que es su unica fuente de ingresos con la cual mantiene a su familia
texts.en:
Ricardo lives in a rented house with his wife and youngest daughter in the city of La Paz. Ricardo has a car, which he uses to provide taxi services over ten hours per day.

This loan will be used to buy tyres for his vehicle; Ricardo's car is his only source of income for supporting his family.antiene a su familia

loans.use: to buy tyres for his vehicle.
